meta_data.title: Nothing Turns the Tables Harder Than the Cross and the Resurrection
meta_data.subtitle: ESTHER 9:1 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Opening song, "" from the album, "" by

transcription_data.text: Hello, my friends, it's Matt. This is a 10 minute Bible hour podcast. I hope you're having an amazing day today. I have strung together a couple of weeks of really good days. I mean, not perfect. A couple of dumb things going on with YouTube. Man, YouTube is frustrating, guys. That is so different than when I started on that nine years ago. They, I don't know, I get into the whole thing. I'm not sure what you do with the YouTube channel anymore, exactly how you make that thing work. And I have really big ideas for a next thing that I'm doing there. I'm working on it. There's a guy that I met who's super talented. His name's Hunter. He's helping me out with stuff. I got some other super talented people who helped me think it through. I'm really excited about what I've got next over there. But yeah, there's some platform headaches. Other than that, I can't really think of anything to complain about in like two weeks seriously. Such good family stuff, fun stuff getting out and playing being in nature. Church has been amazing. I feel nurtured by what is happening at my church. I'm not leading anything or running anything. Other people are ministering to me and my family and the liturgical rhythms, the stuff that we say together that is reflective of what's written down in the Bible. I'm just loving it right now. Communion has been so meaningful of late. And so yeah, it's been awesome. In terms of mostly the stuff I do for work has been awesome with that one little caveat. Friends stuff has been great. Family stuff has been great. Church stuff has been great. Getting outside, doing activities stuff has been great. And it's just been a rich little season here of late. And it made me think this morning that I hope you were experiencing some of the same stuff. I hope you enjoy a rich season, if not right now, very, very soon. And I hope you have the opportunity to pause and breathe and appreciate those golden stretches, those golden times when they come up. All right, I was talking about life a whole bunch. We were talking about the Bible or something like that too. This business about the tables being turned in Esther. I think it's such an interesting turn of a phrase. We dug into that phrase yesterday in Esther 9-1. And it looks like literally how the tables have turned is probably it wasn't euphemism or euphemism, what would you call it? A saying. It wasn't a saying when the Book of Esther was written down, which is we've discussed, I believe, happened somewhere probably in the 400s BC, maybe in the reign of Artaxerxes or Darius II. And at that time, it looks like that probably wasn't a phrase. It looks like the modern English equivalent of the well-known concept though, was the tables had turned. Now Esther and Mordecai were playing from the side of the board that previously, Heyman and his ilk had been playing from and everything was changed and that was massively consequential. And the one who did the turning of the tables is God, whose name doesn't get mentioned at all in the entire book. And it's what a compelling image, that whole thing is, right? You get these two parties are sitting down at the board and they didn't start from a position of equal power, of equal footing, but the one side is just getting their butts handed to them. And the other side is gloating and dominating. And this is a game where when you lose, you die. And then some unseen force comes out of nowhere and without even needing credit and somehow believing that it would be better if his name weren't even mentioned, he just authoritatively, decisively and without anybody being able to squirm or argue, I'm like, that's not fair. You can't do that. It just lifts up the table, flips the board around and is like, there, go ahead and play out the final move or two, just like that. And the fate of everything pivots is just a wild kind of way. So I love that phrase, the tables had turned it. It's captures the imagery of reversal that so characterizes Esther. Well, do you remember way back when we were getting started on this? I think I acknowledged that there was some controversy. There were people along the way, some Jews, some later Christians who looked at Esther and were like, this is a great book, but it might belong in the second tier of Christian or Jewish books that are really important and they tell an important story and they teach valuable lessons, but it doesn't quite rise to Bible. I mean, that was debated. I mean, there's just, there's no point in hiding things like that about how the Bible happened. Some of the books were absolutely agreed upon and never disputed on any level ever. Everybody was always in. Some of the books saw a little bit of debate and dispute. Esther was one of those books. Others were overwhelmingly rejected and never seriously considered as part of the Bible at all, but people still thought they were valuable and we still have some of those today. Esther falls into that lightly debated, somewhat debated category and one of the reasons why is because God doesn't get mentioned in it and because some folks over the centuries read it and were like, it's a beautiful story about Jewish nationalism and that's wonderful that they have that story, but it doesn't really demonstrate how the redemptive plan moves forward. Well, I disagree with that take. I think this is absolutely retained by God to be in the Bible within the canon of scripture. Then one of the reasons is because you're getting to one of the real thin danger spots in all of history where God's redemptive plan theoretically could have derailed and instead of letting that happen, he keeps it on track, even moves it forward assertively without ever even needing to be mentioned in that book. I think that's a very powerful reason to have it in there. But the other reason or another reason I think this just obviously is Bible beyond the obvious excellence of the whole thing is this theme of reversal. Esther sits pretty close to the middle of the Bible. It's the end of the narrative stuff the way most Bibles are arranged and if you go backwards from Esther or forwards from Esther in the Bible, you see that reversal is on either side of it. I mean, think about the whole grand narrative of the Bible. It's a reversal of the curse. It's a reversal of the human problem. It's a turning of the tables on sin and death and entropy and chaos and destruction. And what looks like it should be an obvious L gets turned around into a gigantic W for the glory of God and to the benefit of those who are in him as the story unfolds. So it's not just Esther that is about a turning of the tables. It's the whole thing that is about a turning of the tables. And that's accomplished with a whole bunch of little turning of the tables, micro stories throughout like, Oh, no, God's chosen people are trapped against giant body of water and they got old ladies and donkeys and babies and they got bread strapped to their back. They're totally going to die. The best military in the world is hot on their heels. And then reversal, the sea parts and they walk through is crazy to think about that image and what that means. And you keep crawling through the Old Testament. Oh, no, God's chosen people. They're going to get stuck out in the desert and die because there's nowhere else for them to go. They can't go back to Egypt. They can't stay out here. They've got to go conquer the land that was promised to them. And but it's just it's full of giants. It's really tough. And their first city they come to is a walled city with all kinds of massive problems and weird stuff about it. But you just can't beat it. And if you can't beat it, you're done. You're going to die in the desert and you're going to be lost as a nomadic people group who never found a way to put down roots and then reversal the walls tumble down and they're able to take the land and not die and be eradicated out in the desert. And I understand all of the challenges of any time we talk about war and conquest and all of those sort of things, but reversal after reversal after reversal keeps happening through the Bible. And then you get to the big one, right? This is one of the places where I think Esther points to the big stuff of the Bible. I mean, the grand turning of the tables, it's the cross. Now, whether you're Christian or not, any reasonable reading of the Bible is going to lead you to this conclusion. Sin, death, entropy, failure, chaos, evil, all of this stuff looks like it's going to win because we tried every single way imaginable through the Old Testament to beat it. We tried kings. We tried libertarian societies where everybody did what was right in their own eyes. We tried live and let live. We tried absolute power. We tried using the force of the state to make everybody be more ethical in their Jewishness. We tried exile. We tried kingdoms. We tried judges. We tried prophets. All we do, we tried miracles. We tried not miracles and ages of silence. We tried Greek culture, Persian culture, Assyrian culture, Babylonian culture, Egyptian culture, Roman culture, Alexandrian, Greek, ish. We tried all of that stuff and still none of it worked. The whole thing begs for a turning of the tables and then along comes Jesus of Nazareth. Well, who's going to be the one to defeat evil and fix all these problems? Like some great warrior, nope, it's a teeny tiny little baby who's born under difficult circumstances in a place where you keep your animals. Boom, reversal. Well, this great king is going to come along and he's going to make everybody wash his feet and point out a nope. He washes their feet. Boom, reversal. Well, he's going to do a thing where eventually he marches on the capital in a great show of force, like a great conqueror, like Alexander the Great writing in on his armored war horse to make a statement. Nope. No, he doesn't show up to Jerusalem the way Alexander showed up 300 years earlier. Shows up on a donkey reversal. Well, the religious leaders are going to be the good guys. They'll help everybody be more religious and then the bad guy, he'll get what's coming to him. He'll get crucified, executed on a cross. Nope. Reversal. And all of those little reversals in the story of Jesus, and I haven't even scratched the surface with how many there are. Let me reversal is just kind of the story of the values of the kingdom. It's upside down kingdom with upside down values. All of those reversals in his teaching, and the surprises and the twists that keep happening in the parables in the plot beats of the life of Jesus, they all culminate in the grandest reversal, which is God takes on flesh and then dies on the cross. And he pays for the sins of humanity. He fixes what was broken at his expense instead of assigning those charges to the people who actually need to pay them off. That's quite the reversal. And in that moment, the tables are turned on the human problem, death, sin, failure, chaos, all of that stuff. So I know I've fixated on this phrase for three days now in three different ways, but this is the big one, right? And this is part of the beauty of Esther. We can stretch a bunch of other things like, oh, somebody got lifted up and died and got lifted up on something that kind of resembles a cross, maybe somehow Heyman kind of, yeah, I don't know. Maybe there's some imagery that carries over. But the biggest theme that carries over from Esther to the big, big, redemptive plot of the Bible is the theme of reversal. Then that's what you get in the cross and in the resurrection. And I think it's just magnificent. And that's what I was going to say today. That's what I did. I meant what I said at the beginning, I genuinely hope that you were finding beautiful, awesome, redemptive things in your life right now and that you're able to slow down enough and appreciate the awesome things about this moment. Even if the moment's hard, there's awesome stuff about the moment. And I hope you're able to savor it wherever you're at right now. Then I'm so grateful to you for listening to me talk about what's been a really beautiful stretch in the life of our family. Okay, that's all I got. I'm Matt. This is the 10 Minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.
